content.description: Hard face climbing up thin right facing corner to break, continue up thin cracks to anchors right of triangular blocks.
content.protection: 2 each #0 TCU to #2 camalot with extra #1 TCU's usefull.
content.location: 40 feet left of Bob Can't Climb.

content.description: Four Crack systems right of Bob Can't Climb.  An adventure climb, ie. expect some loose rock and some wide climbing.

climbs.name: Subterranean Homesick Blues
climbs.fa: Andy Donson, Terry Murphy, Steve Crusher Bartlett and Ralph E Burns 2004ish

content.description: Climb wide hands in a corner for 40' then over some solidly stacked blocks up to the chimney, which is easier than it looks.  Goes through a tunnel before popping back out to the anchor on the arete.  Fun and mellow but a bit sandy.
content.protection: Double set from BD .4 to 3.  No wide gear necessary.  A bunch of extending slings are handy.  70m rope
content.location: 40' around the corner to the left of Planet Waves

content.description: Pull up and onto the big flake, then a move or two of fingers into a hands pod. Continue up the narrowing crack with good face holds and one final tricky sequence to the anchor.
content.location: Finger crack on the wall at the mouth of the massive chimney. Hard to see until you're there.

content.description: This route is located on the left side of the established routes.  It is a dihedral just left of Knocking on Heaven's Door. Starts with a bad sized hand/finger crack that quickly changes into a super thin crack.(crux) after passing the crux the crack undulates from fingers to tight hands off and on climbing with a fun sequence towards the top.
content.protection: Camalots from 3.5 down to .2, doubling on most is helpful, stoppers work well and a least one quickdraw for the bolt.

content.description: One of the best on the cliff. Jam, stem, and lieback up the Long left facing dihedral 50 ft left of Obviously Five Believers.  Goes through all the sizes, but bring extra .5 and .75 camalots.
content.protection: Standard desert rack with extra .5 and .75 camalots

content.description: Large open book.  Jam hands to fingers up the obvious black dihedral 50 feet left of Idiot Wind.

this route is super good!! the first pitch is a dumpy very wide crack that ends on a ledge.. there are two wide cracks to choose from to get you to the money pitch.. i would do the right of the two.. it is easier and since you have no gear on either might as well make it easy on yourself.. After groveling to a sick ledge then the fun begins with a fingers splitter (crux) start that widens to hands and rest pods.. Super good route that sees no traffic at all!!!! It is right of all along the watch tower.. ENJOY
content.protection: nothing for the first short wide pitch and finger and hand sizes for the second pitch...

content.description: Climb to pedestal. Clip a bolt then face climb to a left facing flake/crack. Jam crack to the top.
content.location: approximately 80 feet left of All Along the Watchtower.

content.description:
MP comments noting that this section of Isis is a moderate 5.9 has led to it being climbed quite often. So much so that a nice set of chains was added at some point.

A thin-hands start leads to a predominately .75 crack in a left facing dihedral interspersed with the occasional hand sized pod for rests. The .75 section is at what could be considered a layback-friendly angle.

This variation of Isis can be climbed with a 60m rope.
content.protection: The thin-hands start will take 1s. Above that the crack will take as many .75's as you got and a.5 or two if you're open-minded. The hand size pods amid the .75 section can take solid number 1s and maybe a 2 in few spots.
content.location: This is the moderate start of the route Isis. The route is in a left facing dihedral with dark varnished sandstone that transitions into fresh light tan sandstone at the chain anchors after which, Isis proper continues left into a overhang traverse.

content.description: The first half is a great 5.9 warm up- then undercling out the awesome roof, clip the bolt, and then good luck pulling the foothold free transition from the underclings on flared big fingers into the flared chimney. Amazing it goes free, because it seems to just barely go. A worthy send. Would be 4 stars if not for the horrible silt that cakes the wall under the roof and in the upper crack.
content.protection: .75 camalots for the start(4), with 1 camalots(2)in the occasional pod for the first half- .5 camalots (4) out the undercling lieback roof, and orange metolius (4) above the roof. One finger sized piece for the finale(1 yellow metolius). The bolt is essential to keep the rope from jamming in the crack as you climb past the roof.
content.location: Obvious left facing corner with huge leftward undercling roof to a single bolt protecting the lip- finishing in a flare/corner. A 70 meter just barely gets you down.

content.protection: One each 1-3 Camalots, plenty of TCUs or Aliens. Slider nuts work well on this pitch but are not essential.

content.description: This is the huge wide roof on the far right of the wall.  Start with the fingers splitter into the cave and then step out into the massive, wide roof. Established ground-up onsight.
content.protection: In camalots: 1x .2, 2x .3, 1x .4, 1x 2, 1x 4, 3x 6, optional green or blue tube or a VG 9.  Slings
content.location: Far right side of wall.  Starts on the thin splitter into the cave and out the massive wide roof.  Easier than it looks.

content.description:
Climb the left side of the 20ft pinnacle to a large ledge. Take the varnished thin hands crack off the ledge straight up until you've manteled into a Sandy scoop.

A fun, thin line which quickly takes you through thin hands to tips to face climbing past an unprotectable seam. This route has some mandatory climbing above small gear. Just enough pods to keep the protection reasonable.
content.protection: Doubles 000 to 1, single 4 with a long draw. Two bolt anchor with chains
content.location: The varnished thining crack off a pedestal at the top of the approach trail. Easy to spot looking for a bolt 40ft up, just left of this crack (the bolt is for a different route)

content.description: Left of Planet waves about 400 feet find an immense fallen block. The route edges up the wingate slab formed by this block past seven bolts.
content.location: far left side of Dylan Wall

content.description: A long pitch with good variation in size.  Located on the right side of the wall 30' left of a giant overhang.  Climb the right facing dihedral hands to wide hands. Two rope rappel 160'.
content.protection: single set of camalots through 3.5, extra 1 and 2

content.description: Long varied climbing in a left facing corner. Double cracks at the top ease the tension You get a little bit of everything on this route. A good warm-up for the area in my opinion
content.protection: Standard Rack to 3" should do. You can plug a #4 Camalot in a couple spots if you want, but it is not really needed
content.location: Starts on a block in a left facing corner 30 feet right of 'Idiot Wind.' 2 ropes needed to get off.

content.description:
This route is the thin finger splitter to the right of

Idiot Wind

.. As good as anything in the desert!!
content.protection: good selection of tcus, it is a finger splitter after all!!

content.description:
The crux kicks in at the top in the offwidth, before you can get your knee in- sound familiar?

Great climb, and pretty good OW training. On top-rope the second can easily lie-back, making the crux much much easier. Bring the big gear and make this route part of your Dylan wall adventure.
content.protection: At least 3 of each- 1 camalot, 2 camalot, 3 camalot, 4 camalot, 4.5 camalot, and 2 #5 camalots.
content.location: This is the long route on the left side of the Watchtower. The watchtower is the obvious large (approx. 200ft) leaning pillar toward the middle to left side of the Dylan wall. A 70 meter rope barely gets the job done as long as you belay off the small pillar at the base of the route. Consider bringing a knife and webbing to clean up the anchor. A second pitch also continues on, but I have no information to offer.
